FUND NOT HALF SUBSCRIBED
Last Week of Drive Begins with Alumni
Subscriptions Only $122,930—Committee Confident of Success.

The beginning of the last week
of the campaign to raise money
for building the dormitory finds
the total amount given by the
alumni thus far to be $122,930.
Of this amount, $63,930 has been
subscribed during the present
drive. The other $59,000, was
pledged at the alumni reunion
banquet last June. These figures
do not include sums given by persons not connected with the University and those of the undergraduate classes. The donations,

The committee in charge of the
campaign believe that contributions will come in faster after the
personal letter to every alumnus
has been received. If, at the end
of a few weeks, the fund is not
completed, men will probably be
sent out on the street to solicit
subscriptions, as in the endowment campaign of 1910. There
seems to be little doubt that the
money will be raised in time to
begin work on the dormitory next
5pring.

Since it is the plan of the
University to have a reception
hall in the new building furnished
particularly well, this affords an
opportunity for an outstanding
gift.
The undergraduate classes have
not been included in this list and
it is thought that their subscription will be over $10,000.

N inc new members have been
voted into the Omicron Delta Kappa fraternity at the last Meeting
held at the Hopkins Club. The
men who have received this highest honor of the student body are
John H. Lewin, Warren M. Driver, Millard M. Fotird, George
Wagner, Ferdinand Meyer, Harold Townsend, Graham Heiner,
Norman Keyes and George Goetz.
It was decided to have a public
initiation, to be held in the Civil
Engineering Building, the week
befcire the Christmas vacation.
Although the Hopkins chapter of
the fraternity is taking a new
step in adopting such a plan, it is
felt that inasmuch as the organization is a student affair the initiation should be public.
The annual convention will be
held at the Hopkins Club the first
'part of the Christmas vacation.
Delegates from Washington and
Lee, Thividson, and Pittsburgh
will attend.

Mass-meeting Held.

One of the best attended and
most enthusiastic mass-meetings
of the year was held last Friday
in the lecture hall of the Civil Engineering Building in preparation
for the St. John's game. During
the hour before the time set for
the meeting, a large number of
students gathered in front of the
Barn around a coffin upon which
lay the prostrate form of "Old St.
John's." A freshman armed with
one of the famous "Tinfield" rifles
marched solemnly around the body
and held back those who ventured
too near.
Promptly at 12.25, Cheer Leader
"Charley" Leber organized the
crowd into a long column, which
began to march around between
the engineering buildings. First
came the guard, followed immediately by the coffin, which was carried in state by four freshmen, the

BALTIMORE

rest of the parade consisted of a
long line of students walking in
lock-step and yelling at the top of
their lungs. The procession finally proceeded to the Civil Engineering Hall, where a considerable
crowd had already gathered.
The meeting was opened with
several of the University cheers,
which were given in a very enthusiastic manner. Walter Swindell, '97, a former Hopkins cheer
leader, then gave a brief talk.
He told of the difficulties which
he had encountered in getting together enough men to form a
cheering section and said that
with such a crowd as was present
at the meeting, organized cheering
should be a simple matter. He
emphasized the necessity of following the cheer leaders and of
refraining, during the game, from
offering suggestions as to when
and how to cheer. In his closing
remarks, he gave his audience

The Sophomore Class held a
meeting in the Civil Engineering
Hall last Wednesday. President
Goetz called upon. the Constitution Committee to read the class
constitution. After it had been
read . and discussed by several
members of the class, it was ratified by the class without alteration. The committee which drew
up the constitution was composed
of H. D. Caftan, "Jack" Pickford,
E. G. Huey and N. Mulliken.
The Committee on Class Pins
reported that several designs had
been received, one of which would
be selected in the near future.
On account of the great amount of
work at this season of the year,
the jewelers cannot promise to
finish the pins before January.
"Bob" Hall, the treasurer, told
the class that he had a bill to
pay which must be covered immediately by the payment of some
of the dues. The dues, according
to the constitution, will, be one
dollar per year.
smile valuable advice about the
rooting at Saturday's game. '•
Under the supervision of Mr.
Swindell- and the present cheerleading staff, several new songs
an.d yells were practiced. Mr.
Murphy then made. some announcements, one of which was
a call for recruits for the swimming and water polo teams and
another a' request for volunteers
to do some work. for the football
manager. After giving a "hullabaloo" for the team, the meeting
adjourned and the crowd filed out
of the room singing "Razz Those
Soldier Boys."

The first tea to be given this
year by the Johns Hopkins Women's Club was held last Thursday evening, November 20, from
4.30 to 6 o'clock, in Room 326, Gilman Hall. It was well attended
by members of the club, by the
professors and their wives and by
a large number of graduate students.
President Frank J.Goodnow was
invited to speak to the club and
its guests, and he gave an illuminating talk on the previous efforts
that have been made to establish
a League of Nations.
The officers of the club are: Miss
Muriel Ham, president; Mrs.
Buchner, vice-president; Miss
Ethel Hubbard, secretary; and
Miss F. Thies, treasurer. The assistants. Teas of similar nature

BALTIMORE, MD.,
NOV. 25, 1919
Really Awake.

Spirit reached a high point last
Saturday. The megaphones, the
lleW cheers, the parade, the dummy, the bonfire abetted an enthusiasm already aroused by thoughts
of a real conflict. Leber and the
rest of the acrobatic yell directot s had the .cheering section well
it) hand, and that good team of
ow s did get support.
It's just the thing we need—
more good, live "pep" in everything Hopkins does. Besides, it
pays to advertise, and Hopkins
got advertising last week. Staid
Baltimoreans woke up to the fact
that they have a real, howling,
spirited college out at Homewood,
attd not just a handsome group of
Colonial buildings. They may
soon feel natural when they see
the red glow of the bonfire and
neglect to send in a fire alarm.
On Thanksgiving Day we are going to meet an old rival that
Hopkins used to lick, and lick
soundly. Our opponents may have
the edge on us in weight and experience, and some may hold the
odds in their favor, but if the
same spirit makes every man at
Hopkins—senior, junior and soph,
as well as freshman—mass into
the stands and set the very earth
vibrating with intense enthusiasm,
we'll give the Aggies the fight of
their lives, if not a knock-out defeat.

The New Hullabaloo.

When the rumor first Mile to
our ears that our -Hullabaloo,"
the yell par excellence, was to be
cut in half, we were tempted to
send up a cry of horror. Then we
heard a little talk by Mr. Swindell, Class of '97, and came down
to earth. We realized that the
traditional war-cry, so fondly believed to be irreproachable, sounded to the uninitiated like a descent from a coal wagon, and was,
from the middle on, really indistinguishable. We were forced to
admit that the newer version did
have the punch, did carry the
message, and was capable of expressing the enthusiasm of a
crowd of rooters as their united
effort.
By the manner in which the
yell has been received by the majority of students, we feel safe in
stating that the innovation will
be a success. When one of ourselves gets up and says that one
of our hallowed institutions must
be changed, he is ignored or
laughed down ; it takes somebody
frrnn outside to tell us the bitter
truth. The next thing needed is
the composition of three or four
more yells with the same things
in view: punch, coherence and
brevity. The football season is
nearly over, but the lacrosse and
baseball teams need unified rooting as well as the followers of the
pigskin.
In conclusion, we wish to tender our best thanks to Mr. Swindell, and express our hope that he
give us any more tips as soon as
they occur to him.

so participated, when so elected."

Holiday.

The junior athletic football
team, ably piloted by.Mr. Kistler,
will play the third team popularly known as "Jake Miller's Red
Eagles," on Wednesday, November 26, at Homewood Field. The
leaders of the former organization
have viewed the mounting fame
of the Eagles with envious eyes
for some time, and matters finally
culminated in a haughty challenge, which the Eagles' loquacious leader promptly accepted.
A number of junior athletic
basket-ball teams have been organized and trained by Mr. Kistler,
both for the benefit of the players
themselves and for the purpose of
developing promising material for
the 'Varsity. The schethe has
worked extremely well so far; the
men are showing considerable interest in the games and already
three men—Aaronson, Jolson and
Moran—have been transferred to
the 'Varsity squad as likely material. The list of the teams is

Feldman, F. Gerber, Hoffmeister,
Rush, S. Rosenfeld.

Straus, G. E. Manger, H. P. Hoplin,

25, 1919.

EMPLOYEES CHANGE VIEWPOINT

GOOD PROSPECTS FOR

Conditions Under Scheme of Joint
Council Ownership Told by British
Labor Commissioner—Science
Club Gives Dinner.

Basket-ball Has Good Prospects-Several
All-American Men on Squad—
Practice Held at B. A. C.

Dr. Heatherington, of the British Labor Commission, recently
convened in Washington, addressed the Social Science Club
recently after a dinner at the Hopkins Club. In addition to the faculty members and graduate students in the Economic Department, several instructors from
Goucher were present. Dr. Heatherington was secured through
Dr. Lovejoy, who had met him in
England during the war.
The change gradually taking
place in the mind of the workingman and in his activities was the
subject of the lecture. Although
a small group of laborers still
hold to the extreme socialistic doctrine of the abolition of state in
government, there is, on the whole,
a gradual transition in feeling toward the ownership of all means
of production by a high joint council of the state and a representation of the laborers, and the management in the hands of an administration chosen by the laborers in that industry. Stock for
new industries would be floated
by an issue of bonds in denominations small enough to be taken
by the laborers. Control of profit,
after the payment of expenses and
interest on the bond issue, would be
given to the high council. The disposition would probably be made
through an increase in wages, a
return of the surplus to the industry for enlargement, or a redemption of the bonds. For the
factory management, a representative system would be used.; that
is, operation workmen would elect
a fellow-workman, who would in
turn vote for a representative for
the shop, and so on until the managing board for the entire industry was chosen.
As an example of this new theory of nmnagement, Dr. Heatherington told of an airplane factory,
which, after yielding a good return to the promoters, was turned
over to management by the employees. The factory under their
control during the war was run in
such a way as to make it the most
efficient factory of its size in output, management, large returns
and peaceful labor conditions.

TEAM

Fifty candidates, including sevei.al former all - American men
from the Medical School, responded to the call for ,basket-ball material at the meeting last Monday
in Gilman Hall. . The meeting was
opened by Coach Murphy, who
outlined the work for the year
and the team's prospects.
On the evening following the
opening meeting, the initial practice was held at the Baltimore
Athletic Club, and since that time
considerable progress has been
made under the direction of Coach
Murphy and Mr. Kistler.
Among the well-known players
from the Medical School are Cun
and Sheridan, while among
the undergraduates Owens, W.
Wood, Cashell and Calkins are being counted on Iris men who. have
shown excellent form in the past.
PUBLIC LECTURES IN
THE SCHOOL OF HYGIENE

The following is a list of public lectures which will be delivered
in the School of Hygiene and Public Health during the balance of
the session of 1919-20:
Monday, No.vember 24—Mr. Lawrence Veiller, secretary and direitor
National Housing Association, on
"Housing and Health."
Monday, December 15—Sir Arthur
Newsholme, M. D., K. C. B., on "The
Increasing Socialization of Medicine."
Monday, January 5—Dr. Victor C.
Vaughan, professor of hygiene and
physiological chemistry, University of
Michigan, on "The Influenza Epidemic of 1918."
Monday, January 19—Mr. Irwin
S. Osborn, consulting engineer, Cleveland, Ohio, "on "The Collection and
Disposal of Household Waste."
Monday, February 2—Sir Arthur
Newsholme, M. D., K. C. B., on
"Measles Problems."
Monday, February 16—Dr. Frederic S. Lee, professor of physiology,
Columbia University, on "Some Problems of Industrial Physiology."
Monday, March 8—Dr. Allen W.
Freeman, Commissioner of Health,
State of Ohio, on "Public Health Administration of Ohio."
Monday, March 22—Sir_ Arthur
Newsholme, M. D., K. C. B., on
"Early Infant Mortality."
Monday, April 5—Dr. Thomas W.
Salmon, medical director, the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, on
"The Field of Mental Hygiene."

The lectures will be given on
the dates specified, at 5 P. M.,
in the lecture room of the school,
310-312 West Monument street.
The new doorkeeper at the local
museum had evidently learned the
rules by heart before taking over
the job.
"Here, sir, you must leave your
umbrella at the door," he said to
a visitor who was going straight
through the turnstile.
"But I haven't an umbrella."
"Then you must go back and get
one," was the stern reply. "No
one is allowed to pass in here unless he leaves his umbrella at the
door."—Ea.

The Johns Hopkins Choral Society
Announces Rehearsals— Charles
H. Boch-au, Conductor.

Rehearsals of the Choral Society will be held in McCoy Hall at
8 P. M. on Wednesday, November
19; Thursday, I )ecember 4; Thursday, December 11; Thursday, December 18; and Monday, December 22. There will be no rehearsal during Thanksgiving week.
A fee of two dollars is charged
for membership. Among the works
studied will be: "The Song of
Pate" (Brahms) and "Hiawatha's
Wedding Feast" (Coleridge-Taylor). The orchestral accompaniment will be played by the Johns
Hopkins orchestra, at a joint concert to be given by the Choral Society and the orchestra in McCoy
Hall.
Members are invited to bring
friends who desire to join the society. More men's voices are needed, particularly tenors, and it is
hoped that many members of the
University will take advantage of
this opportunity. to study choral
singing. Apply to Mr. Bochau at
'304 East North avenue (telephone
Homewood 3079-4) or at rehearsals in McCoy Hall.
The Choral Society is under the
auspices of the Johns Hopkins
Musical Association, the officers of
which are as , follows: Edwin L.
Turnbull, president; Fred H.Gottlieb, vice-president ; Prof. C. C.
Thomas, secretary, Major G. R.
Guild, treasurer; F. C. Smith, corresponding secretary ; and Maurice
Sneeberger, business manager.

Manager Plans Extensive Trip for Base.

Reputation to Uphold.

Although individually heavier
and superior to the Poly players,
Captain Miller's team was defeated last Wednesday to the tune of
14 to 0. The pick-up nature of the
scrub team was the main cause of
this defeat. The men showed
plainly that they had not sufficient
practice together as a team, and
the backfield showed a marked.
lack of cohesion, as evidenced by
the ease With which Marken
played the positions of full and
tackle alternately. Although the
line was excellent on the defensive, it made few holes on the attack..
Poly on the other hand, played
as well
'as she has played this season. Her interference on the offensive was excellent, and on the
defensive she was on the alert and
prepared for any method of attack.
Hopkins kicked off to Poly,who,
favored with a strong wind, returned with a long punt. The
Eagles were unable to make first
down and were forced to kick.
Poly thus got the ball on the
Scrubs' 30-yard line. By short advances, she made two first downs.
On their fourth down they scored
on a forward pass from Ddrley to
Callis, who caught the ball well
behind the Eagles' goal line. Darley kicked goal.
In the second . quarter, the
Eagles tried a drop-kick from the
25-yard line, but the ball went
wide. Poly likewise tried a dropkick in the third quarter, but also
failed.
In the fourth quarter a blocked
kick, captured on the Eagles 20yard line, followed by a 20-yard
run by Abbott gave the "prep"
school team their second score.

Although it is rather early for
spring sports to come into no-,
tice, the schedule which. Manager Field is working upon for the
baseball team will be a big boost
for Hopkins Athletics.
Last year the team took a northern trip during the spring vacation, playing Yale, Columbia,
Haverford and Swarthmore, and
such a brand of baseball was displayed that the attention of the
northern colleges was drawn not
only to the baseball team, but to
Hopkins athletics as a whole.
Arrangements for even a more
promising trip are under way, and
if the colleges who have answered
up to date are booked, Hopkins
will surely step into the best class
of -teams in the country. As it
now stands, the squad will probably play Princeton, Cornell, Boston College, Holy Cross, Yale and
Fordham during the spring vacation.
Although to complete this schedule in such a short time will put
a strain on the team, and especially the pitching staff, it is felt
that Hopkins will more than hold
•her own, especially as many of
last year's 'Varsity men are still
eligible.

N inc new members have been
voted into the Omicron Delta Kappa fraternity at the last Meeting
held at the Hopkins Club. The
men who have received this highest honor of the student body are
John H. Lewin, Warren M. Driver, Millard M. Fotird, George
Wagner, Ferdinand Meyer, Harold Townsend, Graham Heiner,
Norman Keyes and George Goetz.
It was decided to have a public
initiation, to be held in the Civil
Engineering Building, the week
befcire the Christmas vacation.
Although the Hopkins chapter of
the fraternity is taking a new
step in adopting such a plan, it is
felt that inasmuch as the organization is a student affair the initiation should be public.
The annual convention will be
held at the Hopkins Club the first
'part of the Christmas vacation.
Delegates from Washington and
Lee, Thividson, and Pittsburgh
will attend.

Mass-meeting Held.

One of the best attended and
most enthusiastic mass-meetings
of the year was held last Friday
in the lecture hall of the Civil Engineering Building in preparation
for the St. John's game. During
the hour before the time set for
the meeting, a large number of
students gathered in front of the
Barn around a coffin upon which
lay the prostrate form of "Old St.
John's." A freshman armed with
one of the famous "Tinfield" rifles
marched solemnly around the body
and held back those who ventured
too near.
Promptly at 12.25, Cheer Leader
"Charley" Leber organized the
crowd into a long column, which
began to march around between
the engineering buildings. First
came the guard, followed immediately by the coffin, which was carried in state by four freshmen, the

BALTIMORE

rest of the parade consisted of a
long line of students walking in
lock-step and yelling at the top of
their lungs. The procession finally proceeded to the Civil Engineering Hall, where a considerable
crowd had already gathered.
The meeting was opened with
several of the University cheers,
which were given in a very enthusiastic manner. Walter Swindell, '97, a former Hopkins cheer
leader, then gave a brief talk.
He told of the difficulties which
he had encountered in getting together enough men to form a
cheering section and said that
with such a crowd as was present
at the meeting, organized cheering
should be a simple matter. He
emphasized the necessity of following the cheer leaders and of
refraining, during the game, from
offering suggestions as to when
and how to cheer. In his closing
remarks, he gave his audience

The Sophomore Class held a
meeting in the Civil Engineering
Hall last Wednesday. President
Goetz called upon. the Constitution Committee to read the class
constitution. After it had been
read . and discussed by several
members of the class, it was ratified by the class without alteration. The committee which drew
up the constitution was composed
of H. D. Caftan, "Jack" Pickford,
E. G. Huey and N. Mulliken.
The Committee on Class Pins
reported that several designs had
been received, one of which would
be selected in the near future.
On account of the great amount of
work at this season of the year,
the jewelers cannot promise to
finish the pins before January.
"Bob" Hall, the treasurer, told
the class that he had a bill to
pay which must be covered immediately by the payment of some
of the dues. The dues, according
to the constitution, will, be one
dollar per year.
smile valuable advice about the
rooting at Saturday's game. '•
Under the supervision of Mr.
Swindell- and the present cheerleading staff, several new songs
an.d yells were practiced. Mr.
Murphy then made. some announcements, one of which was
a call for recruits for the swimming and water polo teams and
another a' request for volunteers
to do some work. for the football
manager. After giving a "hullabaloo" for the team, the meeting
adjourned and the crowd filed out
of the room singing "Razz Those
Soldier Boys."

BALTIMORE, MD.,
NOV. 25, 1919
Really Awake.

Spirit reached a high point last
Saturday. The megaphones, the
lleW cheers, the parade, the dummy, the bonfire abetted an enthusiasm already aroused by thoughts
of a real conflict. Leber and the
rest of the acrobatic yell directot s had the .cheering section well
it) hand, and that good team of
ow s did get support.
It's just the thing we need—
more good, live "pep" in everything Hopkins does. Besides, it
pays to advertise, and Hopkins
got advertising last week. Staid
Baltimoreans woke up to the fact
that they have a real, howling,
spirited college out at Homewood,
attd not just a handsome group of
Colonial buildings. They may
soon feel natural when they see
the red glow of the bonfire and
neglect to send in a fire alarm.
On Thanksgiving Day we are going to meet an old rival that
Hopkins used to lick, and lick
soundly. Our opponents may have
the edge on us in weight and experience, and some may hold the
odds in their favor, but if the
same spirit makes every man at
Hopkins—senior, junior and soph,
as well as freshman—mass into
the stands and set the very earth
vibrating with intense enthusiasm,
we'll give the Aggies the fight of
their lives, if not a knock-out defeat.

The New Hullabaloo.

When the rumor first Mile to
our ears that our -Hullabaloo,"
the yell par excellence, was to be
cut in half, we were tempted to
send up a cry of horror. Then we
heard a little talk by Mr. Swindell, Class of '97, and came down
to earth. We realized that the
traditional war-cry, so fondly believed to be irreproachable, sounded to the uninitiated like a descent from a coal wagon, and was,
from the middle on, really indistinguishable. We were forced to
admit that the newer version did
have the punch, did carry the
message, and was capable of expressing the enthusiasm of a
crowd of rooters as their united
effort.
By the manner in which the
yell has been received by the majority of students, we feel safe in
stating that the innovation will
be a success. When one of ourselves gets up and says that one
of our hallowed institutions must
be changed, he is ignored or
laughed down ; it takes somebody
frrnn outside to tell us the bitter
truth. The next thing needed is
the composition of three or four
more yells with the same things
in view: punch, coherence and
brevity. The football season is
nearly over, but the lacrosse and
baseball teams need unified rooting as well as the followers of the
pigskin.
In conclusion, we wish to tender our best thanks to Mr. Swindell, and express our hope that he
give us any more tips as soon as
they occur to him.

EMPLOYEES CHANGE VIEWPOINT

GOOD PROSPECTS FOR

Conditions Under Scheme of Joint
Council Ownership Told by British
Labor Commissioner—Science
Club Gives Dinner.

Basket-ball Has Good Prospects-Several
All-American Men on Squad—
Practice Held at B. A. C.

Dr. Heatherington, of the British Labor Commission, recently
convened in Washington, addressed the Social Science Club
recently after a dinner at the Hopkins Club. In addition to the faculty members and graduate students in the Economic Department, several instructors from
Goucher were present. Dr. Heatherington was secured through
Dr. Lovejoy, who had met him in
England during the war.
The change gradually taking
place in the mind of the workingman and in his activities was the
subject of the lecture. Although
a small group of laborers still
hold to the extreme socialistic doctrine of the abolition of state in
government, there is, on the whole,
a gradual transition in feeling toward the ownership of all means
of production by a high joint council of the state and a representation of the laborers, and the management in the hands of an administration chosen by the laborers in that industry. Stock for
new industries would be floated
by an issue of bonds in denominations small enough to be taken
by the laborers. Control of profit,
after the payment of expenses and
interest on the bond issue, would be
given to the high council. The disposition would probably be made
through an increase in wages, a
return of the surplus to the industry for enlargement, or a redemption of the bonds. For the
factory management, a representative system would be used.; that
is, operation workmen would elect
a fellow-workman, who would in
turn vote for a representative for
the shop, and so on until the managing board for the entire industry was chosen.
As an example of this new theory of nmnagement, Dr. Heatherington told of an airplane factory,
which, after yielding a good return to the promoters, was turned
over to management by the employees. The factory under their
control during the war was run in
such a way as to make it the most
efficient factory of its size in output, management, large returns
and peaceful labor conditions.

Fifty candidates, including sevei.al former all - American men
from the Medical School, responded to the call for ,basket-ball material at the meeting last Monday
in Gilman Hall. . The meeting was
opened by Coach Murphy, who
outlined the work for the year
and the team's prospects.
On the evening following the
opening meeting, the initial practice was held at the Baltimore
Athletic Club, and since that time
considerable progress has been
made under the direction of Coach
Murphy and Mr. Kistler.
Among the well-known players
from the Medical School are Cun
and Sheridan, while among
the undergraduates Owens, W.
Wood, Cashell and Calkins are being counted on Iris men who. have

PUBLIC LECTURES IN
THE SCHOOL OF HYGIENE

The following is a list of public lectures which will be delivered
in the School of Hygiene and Public Health during the balance of
the session of 1919-20:
Monday, No.vember 24—Mr. Lawrence Veiller, secretary and direitor
National Housing Association, on
"Housing and Health."
Monday, December 15—Sir Arthur
Newsholme, M. D., K. C. B., on "The
Increasing Socialization of Medicine."
Monday, January 5—Dr. Victor C.
Vaughan, professor of hygiene and
physiological chemistry, University of
Michigan, on "The Influenza Epidemic of 1918."
Monday, January 19—Mr. Irwin
S. Osborn, consulting engineer, Cleveland, Ohio, "on "The Collection and
Disposal of Household Waste."
Monday, February 2—Sir Arthur
Newsholme, M. D., K. C. B., on
"Measles Problems."
Monday, February 16—Dr. Frederic S. Lee, professor of physiology,
Columbia University, on "Some Problems of Industrial Physiology."
Monday, March 8—Dr. Allen W.
Freeman, Commissioner of Health,
State of Ohio, on "Public Health Administration of Ohio."
Monday, March 22—Sir_ Arthur
Newsholme, M. D., K. C. B., on
"Early Infant Mortality."
Monday, April 5—Dr. Thomas W.
Salmon, medical director, the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, on
"The Field of Mental Hygiene."

The lectures will be given on
the dates specified, at 5 P. M.,
in the lecture room of the school,
310-312 West Monument street.
The new doorkeeper at the local
museum had evidently learned the
rules by heart before taking over
the job.
"Here, sir, you must leave your
umbrella at the door," he said to
a visitor who was going straight
through the turnstile.
"But I haven't an umbrella."
"Then you must go back and get
one," was the stern reply. "No
one is allowed to pass in here unless he leaves his umbrella at the
door."—Ea.

The Johns Hopkins Choral Society
Announces Rehearsals— Charles

Rehearsals of the Choral Society will be held in McCoy Hall at
8 P. M. on Wednesday, November
19; Thursday, I )ecember 4; Thursday, December 11; Thursday, December 18; and Monday, December 22. There will be no rehearsal during Thanksgiving week.
A fee of two dollars is charged
for membership. Among the works
studied will be: "The Song of
Pate" (Brahms) and "Hiawatha's
Wedding Feast" (Coleridge-Taylor). The orchestral accompaniment will be played by the Johns
Hopkins orchestra, at a joint concert to be given by the Choral Society and the orchestra in McCoy
Hall.
Members are invited to bring
friends who desire to join the society. More men's voices are needed, particularly tenors, and it is
hoped that many members of the
University will take advantage of
this opportunity. to study choral
singing. Apply to Mr. Bochau at
'304 East North avenue (telephone
Homewood 3079-4) or at rehearsals in McCoy Hall.

auspices of the Johns Hopkins
Musical Association, the officers of
which are as , follows: Edwin L.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 25, 1919.

10

POLY DEFEATS RED EAGLES

BIG COLLEGES ON SCHEDULE

Hopkins' Third Team Loses by Score
of 14 to 0—Darley and Van
Doren Star for Visitors.

Manager Plans Extensive Trip for Base.
Ball Team—Squad Has Good
Reputation to Uphold.

Although individually heavier
and superior to the Poly players,
Captain Miller's team was defeated last Wednesday to the tune of
14 to 0. The pick-up nature of the
scrub team was the main cause of
this defeat. The men showed
plainly that they had not sufficient
practice together as a team, and
the backfield showed a marked.
lack of cohesion, as evidenced by
the ease With which Marken
played the positions of full and
tackle alternately. Although the
line was excellent on the defensive, it made few holes on the attack..
Poly on the other hand, played
as well
'as she has played this season. Her interference on the offensive was excellent, and on the
defensive she was on the alert and
prepared for any method of attack.
Hopkins kicked off to Poly,who,
favored with a strong wind, returned with a long punt. The
Eagles were unable to make first
down and were forced to kick.
Poly thus got the ball on the
Scrubs' 30-yard line. By short advances, she made two first downs.
On their fourth down they scored
on a forward pass from Ddrley to
Callis, who caught the ball well
behind the Eagles' goal line. Darley kicked goal.
In the second . quarter, the
Eagles tried a drop-kick from the
25-yard line, but the ball went
wide. Poly likewise tried a dropkick in the third quarter, but also
failed.
In the fourth quarter a blocked
kick, captured on the Eagles 20yard line, followed by a 20-yard
run by Abbott gave the "prep"
school team their second score.

Although it is rather early for
spring sports to come into no-,
tice, the schedule which. Manager Field is working upon for the
baseball team will be a big boost
for Hopkins Athletics.
Last year the team took a northern trip during the spring vacation, playing Yale, Columbia,
Haverford and Swarthmore, and
such a brand of baseball was displayed that the attention of the
northern colleges was drawn not
only to the baseball team, but to
Hopkins athletics as a whole.
Arrangements for even a more
promising trip are under way, and
if the colleges who have answered
up to date are booked, Hopkins
will surely step into the best class
of -teams in the country. As it
now stands, the squad will probably play Princeton, Cornell, Boston College, Holy Cross, Yale and
Fordham during the spring vacation.
Although to complete this schedule in such a short time will put
a strain on the team, and especially the pitching staff, it is felt
that Hopkins will more than hold
•her own, especially as many of
last year's 'Varsity men are still
eligible.
